title: E. coli Heat Shock Transformation
original description: This describes a method to transform a plasmid into homemade DH5α cells.
steps:
Set up
1. Thaw competent cells on ice. This takes about 10 minutes. Also thaw the plasmid to be transformed.
2. Warm SOC media to room temperature.
250amount 
NOTES LB media can also be used. Anecdotally, we haven't seen a difference between LB and SOC.
3. Heat a dry block to 42ºC, a shaker-incubator to 37ºC, and a cabinet-style incubator to 37ºC.
4. Label a 1.5mL eppendorf tube for each transformation reaction with the construct name and place it on ice. Label an agar plate with the construct, date, your initials, and plate media type (with antibiotic, if applicable).
RESULT Plate: pYPQ131A  13 March 2018   AR   LB+Tet

Heat Shock
5. Add plasmid to the labeled eppendorf tube on ice.
2amount
6. Add thawed competent cells to the tube with the plasmid and gently swirl with the pipet tip to mix.
45amount 
NOTES DO NOT vortex. Competent cells have very specific and fragile cell membranes that can be damaged by vortexing.
7. Incubate the mixture on ice for 30 minutes.
1800s 
NOTES This time is fungible. Longer is better, but as short as 5 minutes will also work.
8. Place the mixture in the dry block at 42ºC for 30 seconds
30s
9. Incubate the mixture on ice for 2 minutes.
120s

Grow Up
10. Add SOC to the mixture and shake in an incubator
3600s 
250amount
11. (Optional) Spin the bacterial broth for 30 seconds at 6000 rpm, removed 180µL of supernatant, and gently resuspend the pellet in the remaining media to concentrate.
30s

Plate
12. Immerse a plate spreader in 70% ethanol to sterilize and then burn off the excess alcohol.
13. Pipet at least 100µL of the broth onto the labeled agar plate and spread it evenly across the surface of the agar with the sterile spreader. Restilerize the spreader.
NOTES A larger volume can be used, or you can make two plates with different volumes (e.g. 100 and 50µL) to prevent getting colonies that are too close together.
14. Place the prepared plate (lid-down) into a 37ºC incubator overnight (16 hours)
NOTES The plates can also be incubated at room temperature for several days (the weekend).
